meanings.def: to break something, or to be broken, violently and noisily into many pieces
examples: Several windows had been smashed.
He smashed the radio to pieces.
The glass bowl smashed into a thousand pieces.
She flew into one of her rages and started smashing crockery.
His right hand was smashed and his shoulder dislocated.

meanings.def: to move with a lot of force against something solid; to make something do this
examples: + adv./prep. the sound of waves smashing against the rocks
The car smashed into a tree.
smash something + adv./prep. Mark smashed his fist down on the desk.
I was terrified that the plane would crash.
The car skidded and slammed into a tree.
The car and the van collided head-on in thick fog.
Ram-raiders smashed a stolen car through the shop window.
A bullet smashed into the wall behind them.
Ram-raiders smashed a stolen car through the shop window.

meanings.def: to hit something very hard and break it, in order to get through it
examples: smash something + adv./prep. They had to smash holes in the ice.
The elephant smashed its way through the trees.
smash something + adj. We had to smash the door open.
+ adv./prep. They had smashed through a glass door to get in.
He smashed the ball into the goal.

meanings.def: to break a record by a large amount
examples: She has smashed the world record.

meanings.def: to destroy, defeat or put an end to something/somebody
examples: Police say they have smashed a major drugs ring.
He’s smashed (up) his new car.
I was terrified that the plane would crash.
The car skidded and slammed into a tree.
The car and the van collided head-on in thick fog.
Ram-raiders smashed a stolen car through the shop window.

meanings.def: to hit a high ball downwards and very hard over the net
to do something very well or be very successful
examples: After all that training, I’m sure he’ll smash it in the competition tonight.

idioms.def: to do something very well or be very successful
examples: After all that training, I’m sure he’ll smash it in the competition tonight.

related: smash, blow, etc. something to smithereens

meanings.def: an act of breaking something noisily into pieces; the sound this makes
examples: The cup hit the floor with a smash.
He heard the smash of breaking glass.

meanings.def: an accident in which a vehicle hits another vehicle
examples: a car smash
Four people were seriously injured in a head-on smash on the A45.
The smash happened just before junction 13 of the M6.
Their car was involved in a fatal smash with a stolen van.
a 20-year-old victim of a hit-and-run smash

meanings.def: a way of hitting the ball downwards and very hard
examples: He can hit a powerful overhead smash.
He misses a smash to hand Thiem a 5–0 lead.

meanings.def: a song, film or play that is very popular
examples: her latest chart smash
The comedy was an instant smash with critics.
The play was a box-office smash.
They had a smash hit with their debut album.
the recent club smash, ‘Rocking Music’
